page.title: 04CROWHURST CHURCH
page.content: Crowhurst, a small rural parish, is first mentioned in 1189 as "Crauherst" meaning "crow wood". The{Church of St. George}dates from the 13th Century. In the wall of the porch is a stoup which fell into dis-use after the{Reformation.}The font is thought to be Saxon. The basin is a hollowed stone lined with metal. In the chancel are two tombs with interesting brasses, and a tomb which was prepared but never used. There is also an unusual iron tomb set in the floor which is a reminder of the{Iron {Industry }of S.E. Surrey. An enormous hollow{Yew tree}stands in the churchyard.19th Century drawings show a doorway, a table and seats for twelve people inside. A cannonball found here suggests a skirmish between Cromwell's men and the Royalist Angell family who lived opposite the Church.
